summaryInsights.title: Hospital outpatient pricing and site-of-care drift driving ~$1.0–1.6B
summaryInsights.detail: New York spend is structurally elevated as outpatient procedures and infusions continue to shift into higher-cost hospital outpatient settings; reinforcing site-of-care routing and tightening outpatient reimbursement guardrails is the most direct lever to reduce forecast pressure.

summaryInsights.title: Downstate utilization hotspots deviating above statewide norm
summaryInsights.detail: Downstate provider clusters show statistically significant unit-cost lift and utilization intensity in outpatient imaging and specialty services, inconsistent with morbidity changes—indicating behavioral spend that baseline forecasting models absorb as trend.

summaryInsights.title: Imaging and outpatient specialty edits losing effectiveness
summaryInsights.detail: Denied NY claims in advanced imaging and outpatient specialty pathways (MRI/CT CPT families) repeatedly convert to paid through diagnosis reclassification and staged billing, weakening baseline denial yield; tightening exception logic and appeal thresholds will restore control.

summaryInsights.title: Concentration risk among large integrated systems
summaryInsights.detail: A small number of large New York health systems account for an outsized share of outpatient specialty and infusion growth, amplifying state forecast variance; targeted engagement and enforcement with these systems yields disproportionate impact.

summaryInsights.title: Network spillover through shared billing operations and affiliations
summaryInsights.detail: Providers connected through shared billing operations show highly correlated CPT sequencing and appeal success, creating spillover risk where effective tactics propagate across the state; cluster-level interventions reduce systemic exposure.

summaryInsights.title: Behavior-driven spend distorting NY trend assumptions
summaryInsights.detail: After controlling for utilization and morbidity, $2–4B of New York projected spend appears attributable to controllable provider behavior in hospital outpatient migration, imaging, and denial leakage rather than organic clinical demand growth.
